pr_title: DelayedSubscription no longer uses ConcurrentSubscription internally

timeline.message:
DelayedSubscription status and ConcurrentSubscription removal

Motivation:
DelayedSubscription#delayedSubscription doesn't indicate if the
subscription was successfully set. Users of this API may need to take
action based upon this status (e.g. request more data upstream or not).

DelayedSubscription allocates a ConcurrentSubscription internally to
avoid concurrent access on the subscrption when setting the delayed
subscription. This introdcues additional object allocations that can be
avoided.

Modifications:
- DelayedSubscription#delayedSubscription to return a boolean which
indicates if the operation was successful.
- DelayedSubscription no longer uses ConcurrentSubscription

Result:
More status from DelayedSubscription and less object allocation overhead
introduced by DelayedSubscription.

timeline.body:
Considering the case:
1. Initial `requested == 0`
2. Thread 1 invokes `delayedSubscription`, does `requested = SUBSCRIPTION_SETTING`.
3. Thread 2 does `request(0)`, does `requested = -1`.
3. Thread 1 goes to the next for loop iteration and does `delayedSubscription.request(-1)` because `prevRequested == -1`.
While both values `0` and `-1` are illegal according to rule 3.9 it doesn't sound right that we change the original `n` value from `0` to `-1`. I'm not sure if this is acceptable or not.
If not, consider having another state that will represent `request(0)`: `REQUESTED_ZERO = SUBSCRIPTION_CANCEL_PENDING + 1`.

replies.bodyText:
we are overloading the long domain to serve multiple purposes:

concurrency control
accumulation of demand
representing invalid demand
representing cancel

The trade-off is we lose some fidelity (e.g. minimum of 3 invalid request(n) values) on the "representing invalid demand" in order to represent these state transition. Ideally we preserve the original n for debuggability but we use a similar approach in other places to reduce state and consolidate atomic operations on a single field.
We can preserve 0 via some additional mapping/unmapping if we think that is more likely to be used than some other negative number (doesn't seem unreasonable), but also don't think it is a hard requirement based upon the spec.

timeline.body:
I did a quick check on usages of this method and we always call it from `onSubscribe()`. Can we simply disallow calling this method twice? This will do two things:
- Fail fast for unexpected usage (we do not expect this to be called more than once)
- Simplify contract (returned `boolean` should always be `true`)

replies.bodyText:
more aggressive breaking change that could potentially break downstream onSubscribe propagation such that a subsequent onError is called without a prior onSubscribe

The scenario we are talking about is when onSubscribe() is called twice. Presumably the first onSubscribe() correctly went through to downstream, if so, then sending it the second time isn't really expected. Additionally, silently cancelling the Subscription is arguably less useful than bubbling up the error.
Deferring the change sounds good if we are not going out of our way to support it.

timeline.bodyHTML:
If you merge requested and Subscription fields in a single Object state then you can simplify the state-machine and reduce fields here.

(requested handling may be simplified, I haven't thought about it, but this gives the idea of what I am suggesting)

public final class DelayedSubscription implements Subscription {
    private static final AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<DelayedSubscription, Object> stateUpdater =
            AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater.newUpdater(DelayedSubscription.class, Object.class, "state");
    private static final Object STATE_CANCELLED = new Object();
    private static final Object STATE_TERMINATED = new Object();
    private volatile Object state = 0L;

    /**
     * Set the delayed {@link Subscription}. This method can only be called a single time and
     * subsequent calls will result in {@link #cancel()} being called on {@code delayedSubscription}.
     *
     * @param delayedSubscription The delayed {@link Subscription}.
     */
    public void delayedSubscription(Subscription delayedSubscription) {
        requireNonNull(delayedSubscription);
        for (;;) {
            final Object cState = state;
            if (cState == STATE_TERMINATED || cState instanceof Subscription) {
                delayedSubscription.cancel();
                return;
            }
            if (cState == STATE_CANCELLED && stateUpdater.compareAndSet(this, cState, STATE_TERMINATED)) {
                delayedSubscription.cancel();
                return;
            }

            if (cState instanceof Long && stateUpdater.compareAndSet(this, cState, 0L)) {
                long requested = (Long) cState;
                if (requested > 0 || requested == MIN_VALUE) {
                    delayedSubscription.request(requested);
                }
                if (stateUpdater.compareAndSet(this, 0L, delayedSubscription)) {
                    break;
                }
            }
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void request(long n) {
        for (;;) {
            final Object cState = state;
            if (cState == STATE_CANCELLED || cState == STATE_TERMINATED) {
                return;
            }
            if (cState instanceof Subscription) {
                Subscription s = (Subscription) cState;
                s.request(n);
                return;
            }
            if (cState instanceof Long) {
                Long prevReq = (Long) cState;
                if (n > 0 &&
                        stateUpdater.compareAndSet(this, cState, addWithOverflowProtectionIfNotNegative(prevReq, n))
                        || n <= 0 && stateUpdater.compareAndSet(this, cState, MIN_VALUE)) {
                    break;
                }
            }
        }
    }

    @Override
    public void cancel() {
        for (;;) {
            final Object cState = state;
            if (cState == STATE_CANCELLED || cState == STATE_TERMINATED) {
                return;
            }
            if (cState instanceof Subscription) {
                Subscription s = (Subscription) cState;
                s.cancel();
                return;
            }
            if (cState instanceof Long && stateUpdater.compareAndSet(this, cState, STATE_CANCELLED)) {
                return;
            }
        }
    }
}
